articles.headline: Encouraging Numbers, at First Glance
articles.snippet: Although Minnesota’s unemployment rate is relatively low at 6.6 percent, businesses large and small are reluctant to hire, and the depressed real estate market remains a drag on the economy.
articles.abstract: Although Minnesota’s unemployment rate is relatively low at 6.6 percent, businesses large and small are reluctant to hire, and the depressed real estate market remains a drag on the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — When it comes to economic recovery, Minnesota is about as good as it gets.

articles.headline: Why 401(k)’s Should Offer Index Funds
articles.snippet: Index mutual funds are not required to be offered in 401(k) plans, but they should be, because of their many advantages over actively managed funds.
articles.abstract: Index mutual funds are not required to be offered in 401(k) plans, but they should be, because of their many advantages over actively managed funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: The people who help you with your investments ought to act in your best interest.

articles.headline: Former S.E.C. Official Said to Be Subject of Criminal Inquiry
articles.snippet: Federal criminal authorities are investigating whether a former securities regulator inappropriately represented Allen Stanford, the indicted Texas financier, after leaving the S.E.C.
articles.abstract: Federal criminal authorities are investigating whether a former securities regulator inappropriately represented Allen Stanford, the indicted Texas financier, after leaving the S.E.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Securities and Exchange Commission enforcement official who has been accused of repeatedly blocking efforts to investigate R. Allen Stanford, the Houston financier charged with running a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, is the subject of a federal criminal inquiry for having done legal work for Mr. Stanford after leaving the S.E.C., government officials said Friday.

articles.headline: Recovery Seen in Rising Use of Credit Cards
articles.snippet: Consumers have been constrained by the housing crisis, a weak job market and high energy prices, but economists now are cautiously forecasting a turnaround in spending.
articles.abstract: Consumers have been constrained by the housing crisis, a weak job market and high energy prices, but economists now are cautiously forecasting a turnaround in spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the United States emerged from the recession, economists have been watching for signs that Americans are spending again.

articles.headline: Facebook, Foe of Anonymity, Is Forced to Explain a Secret
articles.snippet: The social networking site tried to hide the fact that it was behind a campaign to coax reporters and technology experts to write critical stories about Google’s Social Circle.
articles.abstract: The social networking site tried to hide the fact that it was behind a campaign to coax reporters and technology experts to write critical stories about Google’s Social Circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook, it seems, doesn’t always practice what it preaches.

articles.headline: Health Insurers Making Record Profits as Many Postpone Care
articles.snippet: Companies continue to press for higher premiums, saying they need protection against any sudden uptick in demand once people have more money to spend on their health.
articles.abstract: Companies continue to press for higher premiums, saying they need protection against any sudden uptick in demand once people have more money to spend on their health.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s major health insurers are barreling into a third year of record profits, enriched in recent months by a lingering recessionary mind-set among Americans who are postponing or forgoing medical care.

articles.headline: In Shift, Ads Try to Entice Over-55 Set
articles.snippet: After 40 years of catering to younger consumers, advertisers are broadening their focus to older people for demographic and economic reasons.
articles.abstract: After 40 years of catering to younger consumers, advertisers are broadening their focus to older people for demographic and economic reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 40 years of catering to younger consumers, advertisers and media executives are coming to a different realization: older people aren’t so bad, after all.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: Family Quarrel Imperils a Labor Hero’s Legacy
articles.snippet: A fight among the descendants of the United Farm Workers’ founder Cesar Chavez seems certain to accelerate the decline of a once-powerful movement.
articles.abstract: A fight among the descendants of the United Farm Workers’ founder Cesar Chavez seems certain to accelerate the decline of a once-powerful movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEENE, Calif. — A series of dirt roads in this tiny Central Valley town leads to a warren of homes and offices that has been, for decades, the headquarters of the United Farm Workers union. This is where Cesar Chavez, the labor and civil rights leader, carved out a retreat and raised his family. In a former tuberculosis sanatorium, the Chavez children learned the lessons of the union and listened to endless conversations about the backbreaking work in the nearby fields.

articles.headline: Captive Soldiers Tell of Discord in Libyan Army
articles.snippet: The soldiers, interviewed at a rebel prison, spoke bitterly of their lot but also chose their words carefully.
articles.abstract: The soldiers, interviewed at a rebel prison, spoke bitterly of their lot but also chose their words carefully.
articles.lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — The army and militias of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who for more than two months have fought rebels seeking to overthrow the Libyan leader, are undermined by self-serving officers, strained logistics and units hastily reinforced with untrained cadets, according to captured soldiers from their ranks.

articles.headline: ‘Sex on Wheels’? Now It’s ‘Room for Groceries,’ Too
articles.snippet: Ferrari’s chairman is broadening its lineup with a hatchback but wants to retain the exclusivity of a luxury brand.
articles.abstract: Ferrari’s chairman is broadening its lineup with a hatchback but wants to retain the exclusivity of a luxury brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARANELLO, Italy

articles.headline: Foods With Benefits, or So They Say
articles.snippet: Labels proclaiming health benefits of foods almost shout out in the aisles of supermarkets. But shoppers, and regulators, have their hands full trying to sort it all out.
articles.abstract: Labels proclaiming health benefits of foods almost shout out in the aisles of supermarkets. But shoppers, and regulators, have their hands full trying to sort it all out.
articles.lead_paragraph: START in Aisle 2, third shelf from the bottom: here is grape juice for your heart. Over to Aisle 4: there are frozen carrots for your eyes.

articles.headline: A Low Bid for Fixing a Big Mess
articles.snippet: Although the Raj Rajaratnam trial garnered most of the attention on Wall Street last week, making the foreclosure fiasco go away remained bankers’ biggest worry.
articles.abstract: Although the Raj Rajaratnam trial garnered most of the attention on Wall Street last week, making the foreclosure fiasco go away remained bankers’ biggest worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: SO the feds finally got one: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund tycoon, is going down for insider trading.

articles.headline: Where Water Is an Old Friend, Until It Turns Into a Nemesis
articles.snippet: As waters surge, the homes of thousands of Louisiana residents are being threatened, and so is a way of life.
articles.abstract: As waters surge, the homes of thousands of Louisiana residents are being threatened, and so is a way of life.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUTTE LA ROSE, La. — You do not really want to ask a Cajun why he lives in a swamp, especially when he is packing everything he owns because the very swamp he loves is about to swallow up his house.

articles.headline: Credit Error? It Pays to Be on V.I.P. List
articles.snippet: The major credit bureaus keep a V.I.P. list of boldface names, consumer lawyers say, and those people get special help in fixing mistakes on their credit reports.
articles.abstract: The major credit bureaus keep a V.I.P. list of boldface names, consumer lawyers say, and those people get special help in fixing mistakes on their credit reports.
articles.lead_paragraph: The credit rating bureaus, whose reports influence everything from credit cards to mortgages to job offers, have a two-tiered system for resolving errors — one for the rich, the well-connected, the well-known and the powerful, and the other for everyone else.

articles.headline: Dessert, Laid-Back and Legal
articles.snippet: Dietary supplements promoted as reducing stress and insomnia are easy to buy, but some doctors warn of their harmful effects.
articles.abstract: Dietary supplements promoted as reducing stress and insomnia are easy to buy, but some doctors warn of their harmful effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember melatonin? In the 1990s, this over-the-counter dietary supplement was all the rage among frequent fliers, promoted as the miracle cure for jet lag. Now it is back in vogue, this time as a prominent ingredient in at least a half-dozen baked goods that flagrantly mimic the soothing effects of hash brownies — and do so legally. At least for now.

articles.headline: Secret Desert Force Set Up by Blackwater’s Founder
articles.snippet: Erik Prince has been hired to assemble a force of foreign troops in the United Arab Emirates, according to a variety of sources.
articles.abstract: Erik Prince has been hired to assemble a force of foreign troops in the United Arab Emirates, according to a variety of sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Late one night last November, a plane carrying dozens of Colombian men touched down in this glittering seaside capital. Whisked through customs by an Emirati intelligence officer, the group boarded an unmarked bus and drove roughly 20 miles to a windswept military complex in the desert sand.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Emily B. Hager

articles.headline: Running on Moderation in Immoderate Times
articles.snippet: A moderate Republican, Senator Richard G. Lugar is running on the bet that the Tea Party’s call of alarm has drowned out a majority of Republicans who specialize in reaching across the aisle.
articles.abstract: A moderate Republican, Senator Richard G. Lugar is running on the bet that the Tea Party’s call of alarm has drowned out a majority of Republicans who specialize in reaching across the aisle.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRAZIL, Ind. — Senator Richard G. Lugar had already been introduced to the Clay County Republican Club as “a leader in reducing the threat of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons,” a man of “Hoosier common sense” and “a true statesman for our time.”

articles.headline: Soul-Searching in France After Official’s Arrest Jolts Nation
articles.snippet: The arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn in connection with a sexual attack raised questions about his past behavior and could upend the political calculus in France.
articles.abstract: The arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn in connection with a sexual attack raised questions about his past behavior and could upend the political calculus in France.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The arrest in New York of one of France’s leading global figures and a possible next president, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, on charges of attempted rape produced an earthquake of shock, outrage, disbelief and embarrassment throughout France on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Israeli Troops Fire as Marchers Breach Borders
articles.snippet: Israel’s borders erupted into deadly clashes as thousands of Palestinians marched from Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank.
articles.abstract: Israel’s borders erupted into deadly clashes as thousands of Palestinians marched from Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s borders erupted in deadly clashes on Sunday as thousands of Palestinians — marching from Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank — confronted Israeli troops to mark the anniversary of Israel’s creation. More than a dozen people were reported killed and scores injured.

articles.headline: Skype-Style Calls Force Wireless Carriers to Adapt
articles.snippet: Services like Skype can cut into wireless carriers’ revenue because they offer easy ways to communicate free online.
articles.abstract: Services like Skype can cut into wireless carriers’ revenue because they offer easy ways to communicate free online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Today, long-winded talkers need to worry about running out of minutes on their cellphone plans. But someday there will be no minutes to run out of — just megabytes.

articles.headline: How Drudge Has Stayed on Top
articles.snippet: The Drudge Report, outgrowing its roots in the Lewinsky scandal, is responsible for a surprisingly large portion of the hits at mainstream news sites like WashingtonPost.com.
articles.abstract: The Drudge Report, outgrowing its roots in the Lewinsky scandal, is responsible for a surprisingly large portion of the hits at mainstream news sites like WashingtonPost.com.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most big news Web sites, about 60 percent of the traffic is homegrown, people who come directly to the site by dint of a bookmark or typing in www.latimes.com or www.huffingtonpost.com. The other critical 40 percent comes by referrals, the links that are the source of drive-by traffic, new readers and heat-seekers on a particular story.

articles.headline: Alibaba and Yahoo Try to Make Up
articles.snippet: The two companies are working to resolve a fight that erupted after a regulatory filing last week.
articles.abstract: The two companies are working to resolve a fight that erupted after a regulatory filing last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — It was an unexpected dispute over two continents that floored technology investors.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Verne G. Kopytoff

articles.headline: In This Sky, the Planes Fly Alone
articles.snippet: The editor in chief of Wired magazine hopes to turn autonomous drones into the future of commercial aircraft.
articles.abstract: The editor in chief of Wired magazine hopes to turn autonomous drones into the future of commercial aircraft.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — A father of five and a professed geek, Chris Anderson, editor in chief of Wired magazine, is always looking for child-friendly activities that could, he hopes, inculcate his children with techie sensibilities.

articles.headline: TV Networks Expect a Jump in Spending on Commercials
articles.snippet: As network executives start to share with advertisers and agencies their schedules for 2011-12, ad revenue could grow by as much as $1 billion.
articles.abstract: As network executives start to share with advertisers and agencies their schedules for 2011-12, ad revenue could grow by as much as $1 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox is the only television network that broadcasts “Glee,” but just about every network is gleeful as this week begins.

articles.headline: After Weak Season, Networks Strive for Fresh Ideas
articles.snippet: Acknowledging that last season’s new shows were a washout, the networks are promising something different.
articles.abstract: Acknowledging that last season’s new shows were a washout, the networks are promising something different.
articles.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging that the crop of new television programs last year was almost a complete washout, the networks are spending big this year to promise, if not genuine excitement, at least something different.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Money Troubles Take Personal Toll in Greece
articles.snippet: A year after Greece received a bailout from Europe and the I.M.F., people’s anxiety has grown into deep despair.
articles.abstract: A year after Greece received a bailout from Europe and the I.M.F., people’s anxiety has grown into deep despair.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — His face contorted with anguish, Anargyros D. recounted how he had lost everything in the aftermath of the Greek economic collapse — the food-processing factory founded by his father 30 years ago, his house, his car, his Rolex, his pride and now, he said, his will to live.

articles.headline: Nursing Homes Seek Exemptions From Health Law
articles.snippet: Alarmed at the cost of providing health insurance to workers, many nursing homes are seeking an exemption from the new law, which is intended to ensure access to affordable coverage.
articles.abstract: Alarmed at the cost of providing health insurance to workers, many nursing homes are seeking an exemption from the new law, which is intended to ensure access to affordable coverage.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is an oddity of American health care: Many nursing homes and home care agencies do not provide health insurance to their workers, or they pay wages so low that employees cannot afford the coverage that is offered.

articles.headline: Debt Talks Continue, Minus a Key Figure
articles.snippet: Finance ministers approved a bailout for Portugal and debated new aid to debt-strapped Greece, with a deputy sitting in for Dominique Strauss-Kahn.
articles.abstract: Finance ministers approved a bailout for Portugal and debated new aid to debt-strapped Greece, with a deputy sitting in for Dominique Strauss-Kahn.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers on Monday pressed ahead with efforts to control the debt crisis, approving a bailout package for Portugal and demanding that Greece start a privatization program before it gets any further help.
